posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
sipping on some of "That Camphor Cake" from LP
https://www.liquidproust.com/listing/1188363800/that-camphor-cake-400g
It is a aged white label production sheng cake made sometime in the late 1990's to very early 2000's. Very gnarly looking, lots of stems and large misshapen leaves but the tea is undoubtedly well aged. The cake is aptly titled, camphor is its dominant flavor. Reminds me of moth balls and aromatic cedar with earthy and medicinal undertones. Gives me nostalgic vibes of playing in my grandparents wardrobe as a kid. I was not so sure about this tea the first time I had it, but it seems to have grown on me. Definitely, not an everyday drinker or a tea for everyone but I appreciate having it in my stash.

Thinking of stacking up on my favorite loose tea, some nepalese second flush Kanchanjangha. It somehow struck me. I can only imagine with the quality of the zip-lock the tea can still be considered good decades to come.
Question: Any diehards have a strong opinion against any 30sec->1min soaking? I use a metal strainer and rarely let it pass the two minute mark. I can enjoy a trifle strong assam as well, but rarely divert from this incredibly light, floral and mild nepalese variant I never have fund myself infusing more than once and never diverted from using water still boiling in the kettle. Do you think I'm missing out on something? I have incredibly hard, unfluorinated, tap water.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18931036
More than anything you should try and soften your tap water somehow, hard water really mutes the flavor of tea.
Short infusions like that are okay but you might as well brew the same leaves twice or even 3 times if you want to do that.
First brew 1 minute or so, second two minutes, third four minutes (if it's worth doing)
The later brews won't taste the same but you are missing out by brewing the leaves for a short amout of time.
If you want to decide if you think its worth getting some kind of water filter to deal with the hard water buy a gallon of cheap spring water (poland springs is good for this) and try brewing your tea with it to see what the difference in taste is.
I also have really hard water and i got a filter pitcher from pur and that helps a lot, britta ones also work fine.

posts.com:
>>18935710
First off, those sha qing videos are very relaxing to watch. Second, although I think I disagree with William's definition of "snob" and "snobbery," the class of hobbyist he's describing definitely exists. He cleanly defines a line between the two. An elite may have difficulty identifying he is in the elite when the snob acts like an elite better than he can. He draws some understandable parallels to other fields, military and science that I also found enlightening.
However my favorite part of the video is how bloody well he articulates the necessity of a an objective hierarchy existing in the gamut of a product-based hobby. To not be elitist, as defined at the start of the video, is to not show passion and you might as well be drinking grocery store bags. Or worse yet, one might not have that passion and still have the desire to belong to this community of hobbyists, also known the arrogant snob.
There was also some great little snippets of hierarchy of understanding of tea and thinking about sha qing or tea in general as having layers of abstraction to understand. Darn insightful.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18935823
Puer teabags can be surprisingly decent in my experience.
Use boiling water, put the teabag in the mug and put an inch or two of water in and dunk the teabag and swirl the water around for like 15 seconds. Then dump out that water and fill the mug normally with the teabag in it. Brew 5 minutes at least or just leave the teabag in and drink when it's cooled off enough. It's definitely a different flavor then any tea you might be used to. Exect chocolate, woody mellow flavors. It usually tastes better then it smells

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
www.chinaheritagequarterly.org/features.php?searchterm=029_life.inc&issue=029

I pretty much agree, the general vibe in a lot of hobbies is a sort of intellectual nihilism, centered around the trend of anti-gatekeeping. The central desire is to go to the metaphorical buddhist monastery, and to be told that you are already enlightened, that you were always enlightened and that you just need to realize it. Not the reality, that you will be told that you will be spending the next twenty years of your life at least meditating and studying scripture, and maybe then you will become enlightened along the way some time later. 4chan does well both in killing snobbery, there's no face I have to present to this thread, I have no status or persona here so fighting over it or trying to build my status is pointless; and in promoting the necessarily somewhat violent discussion. No one's posts are put above another, there is no system of upvotes or likes to support a rebellion of the underclass, or the anti-enthusiasts. If you have a strong opinion about tea, you have to lay out your argument and be judged on its merits. Almost especially for tea, I think that this format emphasizes the "jianghu" of tea. There really are not clear lines, everyone has their own extremely strong opinion of what tea is, and you can make very compelling arguments for pretty much any of them. Part of tea culture, at least enthusiast culture, is almost as much arguing about tea as it is drinking tea. Forming an opinion, developing it, and then presenting it passionately is part of the fun. I think it's especially enjoyable without the sort of nonsense that comes with forums, and communities that promote snobbery.

Holy shit it's identical, you're just skipping the whole point, which is to make sure there's nothing left over on the fucking utensil.

It's a simple concept: a utensil with a lot of surface area means a lot of area that something like honey will stick do. If you're making something (like a sauce) later that needs some liquid sweetener anyway, you can use water to remove all the excess honey from the utensil (or analogous sticky substance for analogous applicable food) because the honey dissolves easily in water. Thus you get virtually zero wasted honey and an easily cleaned utensil. This should not be fucking controversial, yet everybody is hung up on the idea that as soon as water touches something it becomes "dishwater" like a bunch of fucking 5-year-olds.

Roasted chicken legs for dinner tonight! I'm gonna do some other stuff too, though, and make it gluten and dairy free. Not because I'm intolerant or anything, just because I feel like it...

0.5 tsp black pepper
0.5 tsp white pepper
0.5 tsp garlic powder
0.5 tsp chili powder
and about 0.25 cup crushed tortilla chips

>>18931288
Fast food is good for anything fried. It saves you the trouble of dealing with large amounts of fry oil, having a deep fryer or mess wok setup, and saves you the waste from breading stuff. Major labor savings here.

Sandwiches (unless fried) are the goto for making at home. Super easy to make, you can keep all the ingredients in the fridge, and if you want it toasted you have plenty of options: oven broiler, toaster oven, air fryer, etc. Microwave is there for heating ingredients if needed.

Hard to make soups are great to do at restaurants. Things like pho, ramen, bisques, and so on. These things take lots of time, so having it made for you is great.

Burgers and steaks should always be made at home. Both fast food and restaurants are fucking you here. They just can't deliver the quality a home cook can, period.

Pizza is definitely a restaurant thing, just because doing it at home requires expensive custom setups to do right. To even compete you need a dedicated pizza oven and then all the proofing equipment and time to do that crap. And the pizza oven only does 1 thing: pizza. Not to mention you have to get super autistic about the process & ingredients. At least a grill makes many good things.

Sushi is one of the other things that is better to leave to a restaurant. I've tried making it myself, and it is definitely harder (and riskier) to do yourself. Not to mention supply issues with finding proper sushi grade fish.

Reminder that 95% of scotch distilleries are owned by multi-national corporations, import barley from countries overseas such as Turkey and Egypt, do the malting offsite, buy peat from other regions of Britain, use lab-created yeast for their mash, use barrels made from American or Spanish wood, and add caramel coloring to the final product.

The only thing authentic about any particular region or scotch distillery is the water or copper stills, both of which could hardly be said to contribute any unique flavor profile to the scotch over any other distillery.

The only thing that gives a scotch an authentically unique flavor profile that is not imported from elsewhere is the process by which the components are put together, i.e. smoked peat, grain ratios, etc. This is a process, which has nothing to do with utilizing the resources of the terroir.

All of this wouldn't be so bad if it wasn't for the over-insistence that each distillery possesses a unique terroir. French wine for example has much stricter requirements for the definition of something like Champagne. If the grapes don't come from Champagne, it is not Champagne.

>>18930663
I got one of those Zojirushi Japanese rice cookers and it's become one of my favorite kitchen items.

There's the obvious benefits:
Rice is always cooked perfect, better than I do in a pot, it's easier, I can't mess it up, and the cleanup is easier.

But the really big one that you don't realize until you have one is that it's fire and forget. Before you start cooking you load it up and start it and you never have to worry about the rice again until you need it. This thing cooks the rice perfect by itself and then can keep it warm and at perfect consistency for over 12 fucking hours. When you need the rice you just open it up and scoop it out.

Also it plays twinkle twinkle little star to let me know when the rice is done. (Japan you silly.)

posts.com:
Pretty bad. Varies a lot, actually. Some prisons have farms, and they sometimes eat OK, if the food isn't intended for sale to the public. I've been in small county jails with no kitchen facilities that serve frozen tv dinners 3x per day. Varies wildly. From nutriloaf level forms of culinary punishment to decent cafeteria care, but generally it's pretty fucking bad. Expired ingredients, weevil infestations, poor sanitary conditionss and such are not uncommon.

That being said, I spent a month in juvenile as a kid, and I ate better than I ever did at home, though that's probably more a reflection on my mother than the quality of food served by the state.

>>18936222
I followed the YouTube instructions. Indians roast everything in ghee, pretty much. You don't need much, a table spoon or two
Chop dates with knife (fresh dates,"first fruit is jeetspeak for nuts)
Roast nuts in wok. Only a couple minutes. Add seeds. Anyone minute or so.
Add coconut and cardamon, then the dates. Mix it up in there. Pour it out on table and make balls with your hand as soon as it's cool enough you can stand to do it. Wet your hand with water to stop the sticking. They say to use ghee on your hand, but that shit is expensive here.
It's pretty easy. I put them in the fridge, but they are temperature stable for weeks.
The wife and daughter eat them like candy, but they got dinner and vitamins and shit.
There's runs of versions in YouTube, but this one is mine.

>>18924203
Traditionally in the US steak was cooked well-done until the 1930's. Because of the Dustbowl (look it up, kids) and rail disruptions it was impossible for the New York steakhouses to get the top-quality beef from Texas and Oklahoma they were used to. The lower quality beef was tough to begin with and some cuts were worse. So the restaurants in New York switched to sirloins as the default and so on.
They also started cooking these leaner cuts medium rare to both take advantage of the lean and to hide the lower quality of the steak itself.
Sauces and such also leaped into use because of this. The UK developed Steak Diane in a similar move to hide the low quality of beef during the worst of teh Depression.
AS the tony nightspots in New York and London adopted these tricks to cover and stretch cheap, low-quality meat it was replicated across a lot of Europe and (especially) the US such that a few generations later the majority of Americans associate 'medium-rare-' with 'high class' to the point they extend it to ridiculous things like hamburgers, massively increasing the risk of food bone pathogens but at least they aren't 'acting lower class', amirite?

>Overdone is better than nothing. Right?
>I like jerky and overcooked steak/chicken/pork is like super thick jerky.
There's a reason it's called "well done" and not "overdone". If the meat tastes dry and tough or rubbery then it's overdone, just like it would be with fish or chicken. The point of doing "well done" well is that the cooking is timed precisely to stop when the meat is cooked through. In that sense it arguably requires more skill than to do any other steak preparation, unless you're do it sous vide or something.

tldr: if it's "overdone" it's not "well done". Under, over, over, done.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18932250
>1:3 ratio of yellow turnip to kennebec (any non waxy potato is kosher) iirc i did 1kg of potatoes and had a 300g turnip
>250ml of heavy cream
>5 garlic cloves minced/microplaned
>tablespoon of kosher salt
>tsp of white pepper
>tsp of black pepper
>tbsp of tallow/butter/lard
>heat cream, minced/planed garlic salt, pep, tallow until almost boiling and transfer to SS bowl
>peel pots and turnups and mandoline/meat slicer/cut as thin as possible like ⅛" into bowl of hot cream
>toss a few times to evenly distribute seasonsings
>either layer in a cake pan of whatever size or layer in a 4" ring mold with foil on the bottom
>if using cake pan fill another full of hot water with a foil on the bottom and weigh down the potato mixture and bake at 400f until fork tender

>ideally fill cake pan 1/3-1/2 at max cause cream boil over, put a baking tray below your cake pans
>if using ring molds use an empty soup can that fits and fill with beans or use a all metal olmypic weight to weigh the can down
>once fork tender after like 30-40 mins unmold/un weigh and bake at 450f for 5 mins to crisp up
thats aboot it

>>18933170
Not hard at all, very crispy. It's like ultra-crispy cracker jack. The big issue I still have is that popping the kernels in molten sugar makes it hard to remove unpopped kernels. Also again, it's dangerous. I wear long, heavy gloves and safety goggles when I make it. It's a bit difficult as well, since the temperature difference between where popcorn kernels pop and where sugar burns is pretty slim.

It tastes pretty good, but it's mostly just a fun challenge I like to mess with. Sometimes I wish I had some lab equipment...

posts.com: Hey CK, I followed some of your advice on my make jerky at home journey. Some of the advice was great. Some of it only made slight differences. For me making jerky needs 4 ingredients to be tasty, the sodium bicarbonate prep is not necessary, and using lean meat is best. Only necessary step is marinading for at least 12 hours in a mix of soy sauce, a vinegar based hot sauce and a bottle of beer.(I've been using an imperial IPA.) After the marinade period I sprinkle black and chipotle pepper over each drying rack before turning the dehydrator on. Turns out amazing in about 7-10 hour depending on the thickness of the beef.

>>18932858
I find fake meat morally repugnant. Properly done, regenerative farming is quite good for the environment and results in great living conditions for the animals. All of these plant based products require ever more massive tracts of land for growing corn and soy, which is quite destructive. Tilling up thousands of acres of land releases tons of sequestered CO2 into the environment and destroys natural habitat for plants and animals. It requires far more fuel to be burned, and ever more complicated industrial manufacturing techniques. Over time growing those crops depletes the soil, and requires expensive and dangerous chemical fertilizers and pesticides.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18934408
I eat them once a week, on average. Testicles are a local delicacy (but folklore to me), brains, sweetbread, liver, tripes and kidneys are more regular fare. They look perfectly appetizing to me, when fresh. In winter I add paws, tails, ears, tongues, pressed face. I find plastic packaging utterly disgusting and ads irritate me so much they chase me away.

Turn brains into a brain croquette (absolutely delicious) and I start having problems because I can't check if the brain is fresh any more. Same for sauces of course. Needless to say I make my own bread and most of my pickles/vinegars/tabasco. I buy dairy, wheat, wine, beer, olive oil, fruit&eg and mustard straight from the producer. Herbs and flowers come from my garden and spices from a Michelin star chef who travels the world looking for the best crops.

Minced meat needs to be meat, minced, full stop. The butcher minces the piece I choose in front of my eyes. No salt, no pepper, no breadcrumbs, no 75% porc and 5 % beef. No minced meat that's 82% meat.

Proper produce, minimal manipulation, sauces in support of the product. Autistic heaven.

>>18934237
I got some from my bacon. I cut and slow-fry my bacon in rather thick slices and give them at least 40 minutes in total.
I have dabbled a bit lately with pork, and pork really takes time to taste well, and I far from eat it every week, yet I still save up the lard for perhaps some beef casseroles, like one with chili, beans, celery, onion and and green pepper. Chili casseroles with well-sizzled bacon is okay, but honestly, beef is better.The lard is well spent, however, with some tomato sauce, cumin, garlic and crushed black pepper.
So far it goes well with eggs, too, but mostly I use coconut, olive, sesame or butter for different stuff. I guess if I could keep the amount of lard down under one tenth in total I wouldn't mind it at all.

I had a feeling I would stick with bacon in regards to pork in general but lately I had to try the classics just to be sure I could make them.
Italian sausages with pork are tastty, but I can't really vibe that much with the usual nordic pork products besides perhaps the annual oktoberfest würst or another annual rib sandwich. It's so damn hard to digest, really.
Just a tiny bit lard in some recipes is delicious I think, but it's one fat I'd rather not overuse, just like sesame or cheap sunflower/rapeseed oil.

For thicker cut filet mignons you should reverse sear.

preheat oven to 225, season with only salt.
Use a thermometer placed in the center of the steak, and wait until it reaches 125-129 internal.

Pull steaks, add generous amount of oil to thick cast iron or carbon steel pan.
Max heat.
Wait until oil starts smoking
Add steaks, start timer, and flip every 15 seconds until your timer reaches 2 minutes.

Season with cracked pepper. Enjoy.

>>18931124
Tilapia's nutrition isn't as great as the benefits touted by the oily fish including the salmonids, but it's still a fish that's a better source of omega 3s than other meats, whether wild or farmed.

Regarding cooking, I agree that it's a pretty tasteless white fish, but if you just need that texture then there are plenty of recipes for which it can be essential.

The most basic way I know of to prepare bland cheap tilapia filets is to rub both sides generously with ground cumin and fry that up in like 2 T of oil. Cumin is quite cheap in the bulk containers and will act as both flavoring and similar to flouring. Salt and pepper to serve, plus lemon and maybe olive oil to taste is as simple as it gets. Look also for filets with a good bit of skin or ask the fish dude to leave the skin on when they scale it -- in the West they remove the skin from a lot of the pre-cut filets, and the skin being mostly fat will add a lot of flavor (that's why they love it in Asia).

The better quality your avocado, the simpler and more fresh your guac should be. In essence: avocado, salt, citrus or light acid, and cilantro (or parsley or similar if your guest hates it).

If your avocado is less fresh, or you're using a more local recipe, then you can roast your garlic, chilies, and (if using) tomatoes/tomatilloes before adding, which adds complexity and helps cover up any funkiness that someone might detect in older avocados. I make guac like this with brown clearance avocados all the time and people never notice that -- they more take notice that the ingredients are whole and grilled.

It depends on the oil he used, the temp he was using to polymerize, and how thick of a layer of oil he was using, if it was a sufficiently thin layer, at the proper temp, allowed to cool down between coats, etc. It COULD be pretty decently strong.

However it could also be dogshit if he was lazy or using the wrong oil or too much oil.

And with 100 coats unless he followed the same procedure for each coat, there is a chance the differences could lead to internal stresses that can lead to flaking/cracks in the seasoning later.

Lodge survived the Great Depression, and continued to make a profit for decades after better cookware technology has dominated the market. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Nonstick:
>Easily scratched and ruined forever
>Toxic chemicals if heated to too high of a temperature
>Loses heat quickly

Steel or Aluminum:
>Dent easily if dropped
>Don't hold heat very well
>Food sticks if using low amounts of fat, which you probably are if you're camping or hiking

Cast iron:
>Can handle some abuse
>Holds heat very well
>Can be placed directly into embers and covered with them (Lid on of course) to act as an oven allowing a larger range of dishes to be made
>Clean up can be done with just some salt and finished by setting it back over the fire to dry and you're good to go

Durability + Different usages.

Food carts in Portland are excellent. While in most cities like LA and NYC people brag about going to expensive or exclusive places, people in Portland brag about going to the cheapest, most dirty, hole in the wall and least known places, allowing the food cart industry to thrive. They are almost all at least decent and far better than fast food. That said, given the economy and trendiness, prices have risen significantly and instead of a great deal for good food, it has become somewhat of a novelty in recent years.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Anons in previous threads talked about matjes and spreading it on rye toast and it stuck with me. Then today I saw whole cured herring was the cheapest fish per pound, and there was a big bag of European-style rye bread in the discount bin.

It's vacuum-packaged schmaltz herring from Haifa brand, and a little disappointingly it came already gutted and boned. The former is understandable but not the latter. Also, all the online recipes say to soak for like 12 hours, but after only a really short soak it no longer tasted salty at all, so I don't know if that vacuum sealed bag required less curing or what.

Because the soak was so short, I started pickling tonight around midnight, using something like this first NYT recipe (though based on other recipes it seems like I have to adjust the amount of liquid in the jar to cover the stupid fish with a mix of vinegar and water). Pic related is what my brine jar looks like at the end of the night before going into the fridge for a few days (we'll try one fillet tomorrow first).
https://cooking.nytimes.com/recipes/883-pickled-herring-three-ways

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18934911
Not melting is usually caused by high protein, low water, or high/low pH, which can all happen in cheese that's not highly processed. Higher protein cheese is just made from skim milk, and taking a layer of fat off some milk is barely any processing. In the other direction, American cheese melts fine, but it's made from ground-up real cheese that's melted then combined with other stuff.

Modern steel is better than the high end shit from years ago. Buy a cheap name brand knife and learn to sharpen it. The practical difference between a low and high end knife is the high end steel will hold it's edge slightly longer. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18935606
>cast iron pans
Lodge is fine, just use some sandpaper to smooth out the surface and wash + season it after every use. Others will disagree; they're cooking with filthy pans.

>dutch ovens
Le Creuset is genuinely great, but expensive as hell. You can get 80% there with a dutch oven that costs 1/8th as much.

>roasting pans
I don't think you need one.

>knives
Learn how to sharpen a knife and how to keep your fingers out of harm's way. You can break down a chicken or root vegetable with a $2 paring knife; it's just gonna be a little more hassle. Get a few stones with no grit higher than 1,000.

>cutting boards
Get whatever, just keep it clean. If wood, apply a little mineral oil; that can be shared with your sharpening stones.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>18932313
The problem is that gluten is a pretty important part of many flour-based recipes (pasta, pizza/kneaded breads), so you can't just use any powder as a substitute. Not only do you need some sort of gluten substitute, you need stabilizers/emulsifiers as well to get it to work similarly to gluten-containing flour. Even then, it's a pale approximation. I've seen gluten-free "flours" containing powdered egg and ground chickpea as the gluten/protein alternate, with xanthan gum and tapioca powder to stabilize and emulsify, and other fillers like rice flour as the main starch component. If you wanted to make your own, getting just the right mix would take quite a bit of R&D.

If the latter, you have much more leeway with the general presence of gluten and don't have to be completely autistic about it, assuming your doctor did the differential diagnosis correctly (he should have done a blinded test on you among other things).

>>18932074
>constantly sickly and frail over a fucking meme.
I've never heard of this as an identified symptom of NCGI, either anecdotal or confirmed.
>he main symptoms in patients with NCGS include abdominal bloating and pain in the upper or lower abdomen, diarrhea, nausea, aphthous stomatitis, alternating bowel habits, and constipation. These symptoms are also common in other functional GI disorders, particularly IBS and functional dyspepsia. ... . In addition to experiencing GI symptoms, patients with NCGS most often experience a complex of extra-intestinal symptoms, including a “foggy mind”, which is described as an inability to concentrate, reduction of mnemonic capabilities, and lack of well-being as well as tiredness, headache, anxiety, numbness, joint/muscle pain, and skin rash/dermatitis.
https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6182669/
Really the only way to confirm there is *some* form of diet sensitivity going on is the double-blind-placebo-controlled gluten challenge (or equivalent with overlapping diet restrictions like FODMAP). If the doctor didn't do that with you (because it's a pain in the ass to do that would be logistically impossible with every IBS patient), then they didn't make a formal diagnosis, but rather are just having you try a possible treatment.

“Gluten intolerance” is a thing according to most research, and it isn’t caused by carbs.
It has been proven as a cause of GI issues, but not conclusively on non-digestive problems, and there is evidence that other proteins and antigens in wheat could be causes rather than gluten alone.

But it is way overboard to make a blanket statement that non-celiac gluten or wheat intolerance is fake when the science shows much more nuance.

I posted the updated review. The point is not to disagree with your doctor, but I'm asking specifically whether you were definitively diagnosed as NCGS, or are just being recommended the gluten-free diet because you report it is working. As I will explain:


>>18934590
>>18935155
A range from 50% to 80% of patients being blind tested for some kind of gluten, wheat, or FODMAP sensitivity (see limitations) showed some degree, or entirely, nocebo or other psychosomatic effect. That still leaves, regardless of where the stats get refined to in a few years, 20% to 50% of NCGS patients who can, in a blind or double-blind controlled setting, reliably differentiate between identical-looking gluten and gluten-free products. Whatever it is, whether it's entirely a subset of FODMAP sensitivity or whatever, it's real (but in most people it's a bullshit fad, which is why it has to be diagnosed, correctly, ideally in a controlled setting -- which again would be a waste of time/resources to do in every case, so quicker dirtier methods are necessary, mostly just involving telling the patient to continue gluten-free if it makes them feel good, since in the end following any form of diet restriction results in generally healthier eating habits in the 1st world).
https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6630947/

>>18930862
Butcheranon here, I recommend using a glutenous filler to hold the meat together and to keep the juices and fat from running out as you cook. Use some dried and fresh spices and cook to medium rare to rare and let the patties rest for a couple minutes to avoid losing your juices.

-500g fresh ground beef, not too lean but not fatty either. Ideally you have a mincer and ask the butcher to buy trimmings to make your own mince (beef mince is a waste byproduct from breaking down quarters into cuts)
-about 1/2 tbsp filler. Most burgers you eat probably use rice flour but breadcrumbs or plain white flour will do
-1/2 tsp smoked paprika
-1/2 tsp onion powder
-1/2 tsp garlic powder (a pressed garlic clove or 2 is even better)
-1 tsp fresh chopped or dried herbs
-salt and freshly ground black pepper
-a sprinkling of dried chili flakes
-1 tbsp water

If you're doing the recommended method with a mincer, mix all the ingredients in a bowl together by hand and run the mix twice through the mincer and form into patties. If you're using preminced beef, use your hands to mix the dry ingredients and beef once, then add the water and mix again to evenly distribute the seasoning and filler.
This recipe will either yield about 3 6oz burgers or 4 smaller patties.
Ideally you're grilling them but you can also cook them in a pan. Cook on high/medium high until medium rare and let them rest for at least 2 minutes before eating

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Like all vegetables I cook, I cover parsnips when i cook them. They end up cooking in the steam from their own internal water, and I consider them done when they're totally soft and mushy throughout. By this point some natural caramel will have formed on the bottom of the pan or roasting tray just from the parsnips' own sugar.
People would say cooking them until soft is overcooked, but no, that's just cooked through. If it's still crunchy in the center then that's simply a raw uncooked center. And to get some browning or crisp on the outside I may then turn up the heat, uncover, and let them roast like that until brown.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>18912357

For a while, up until recently I had a very unhealthy hydration routine...well, there was no routine.

I would have a strong coffee when I woke up, go to work, have a diet soda while I was at work...then when I came home have another diet soda (caffeine free this time)....

But the weird thing is I was never THIRSTY. Thus I didn't really "drink" that much fluid or water. But honestly I don't know I didn't suffer more effects from this. It comes out to very little water.

But I have noticed I've gotten very infrequent bowel movements...and that's what disturbed me and inspired me to change my habit. I don't eat too much to begin with, but I think the lack of water slowed everything down...and diet soda is not good for you gut apparently either.

So recently I started to try and make a point of drinking a bottle of water when I wake up, and substituting water wheras before I would drink diet soda.

Does it suck? Yes. But I think it's one of those things where when you have a habit for a long time, you have the initial "shock" of changing the habit, but then have to "rewire" yourself slowly over time.

Basically I have to readapt to drinking plain pure water often. The last few days I've been trying to cut out diet soda entirely. I think it's probably for the best. Time will tell if it leads to any real improvement.

Diet soda is strange in the sense that it's possible to not feel any negative effect at all...but perhaps once it's taken away I will notice positive changes

posts.com:
I make a pork curry fry with bitter lemon that I'd bet would be just as good with grapefruit.
Just toss cut up pork with tenderiser powder and powdered spices (mix them yourself or just use your favourite curry powder) and par-fry then remove from the pan.
Next, add shredded or grated ginger and sliced red chilli and sautee until fragrant then re-add the pork and its cast off juices.
Sautee a bit then make the slurry: in a jar with a tight fitting lid, put the juice of a bitter lemon (or grapefruit in your case), a pork stock cube, some sugar, a bit of dark sesame oil, a bit of light sesame oil, some water, some mushroom seasoning powder and some cornflour/cornstarch then lid the jar, shake to combine and pour into the pan.
Add cut-up onion and green capsicums/bell peppers and toss about then reduce the heat to simmer.
Once the onion is cooked to your desired doneness, off the heat and stir in fresh coriander leaves, chopped spring onion and the zest from the lemon/grapefruit and serve with rice.
It's quick, good and easy.

>>18932772
>Write a recipe using 100lb of grapefruits as the main ingredient

Grapefruit Coconut Ice Cream

Ingredients:

• 100 lbs of Grapefruits
• 1 quart of Half-and-Half
• 2 cans of Sweetened Condensed Milk
• 1/3 cup of White Sugar
• 1 teaspoon of Vanilla Extract
• ¼ teaspoon of Salt
• 2 cups of Sweetened Shredded Coconut
• 2 tablespoons of Coconut Oil

Instructions:

1. Peel and juice the grapefruits, collecting the juice and discarding the rinds.

2. Place the juice in a medium saucepan and heat over medium-high heat for about 5 minutes or until the juice is reduced by about half.

3. Remove from heat and let cool for 5 minutes.

4. In a large bowl, whisk together the Half-and-Half, Sweetened Condensed Milk, Sugar, Vanilla Extract, and Salt until combined.

5. Slowly add the cooled grapefruit juice and whisk until combined.

6. Transfer the mixture to a large container and freeze for 4-6 hours.

I think the proportions might be off but the concept is good. Make an absolute grip of grapefruit ice cream, seems delicious.

I like this. I made a couple.

>Write a recipe using ground beef and honey

Honey Garlic Ground Beef

Ingredients:

1 pound Ground Beef

2 tablespoons Olive Oil

3 cloves Garlic, minced

2 tablespoons Honey

2 tablespoons Soy Sauce

1 teaspoon Fresh Ginger, grated

1/2 teaspoon Salt

1/4 teaspoon Black Pepper

Instructions:

1. Heat the olive oil in a large skillet over medium-high heat.

2. Add the ground beef and cook, breaking it up with a wooden spoon, until it is browned and cooked through.

3. Add the garlic, honey, soy sauce, ginger, salt, and pepper and cook, stirring occasionally, until the garlic is fragrant and the sauce has thickened, about 2 minutes.

4. Serve over hot cooked rice or noodles. Enjoy!

>Write a recipe using stew meat, olives, and sweet potatoes

Moroccan Stew

Ingredients:
2 lbs stew meat
2 cups pitted green olives
2 sweet potatoes, cut into cubes
1 onion, diced
1 red bell pepper, diced
2 cloves garlic, minced
1 teaspoon ground cumin
1 teaspoon ground coriander
1 teaspoon ground ginger
1 teaspoon paprika
1/2 teaspoon cinnamon
2 cups vegetable broth
4 tablespoons olive oil
Salt and pepper

Instructions:

1. Heat the olive oil in a large pot over medium-high heat.

2. Add the stew meat and season with salt and pepper. Cook until the meat is browned on all sides, about 10 minutes.

3. Add the onion, bell pepper, garlic, cumin, coriander, ginger, paprika, and cinnamon. Cook for another 5 minutes, stirring often.

4. Add the vegetable broth and sweet potatoes. Bring to a boil, then reduce heat to low, cover, and simmer for 30 minutes.

5. Add the olives and cook for an additional 10 minutes.

6. Taste and adjust seasoning, if needed. Serve hot.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>Write a recipe using frog legs, chipotle peppers, and mint

Chipotle Frog Legs with Mint

Ingredients:

-12 frog legs
-2 tablespoons of olive oil
-1-2 chipotle peppers in adobo sauce, finely chopped
-2 cloves of garlic, minced
-1 teaspoon of salt
-1/2 teaspoon of black pepper
-2 tablespoons of freshly chopped mint
-1 lemon, cut into wedges

Instructions:

1. Preheat the oven to 375 degrees Fahrenheit.

2. In a shallow bowl, mix together the olive oil, chipotle peppers, garlic, salt, and black pepper.

3. Dip the frog legs in the mixture and make sure they are evenly coated.

4. Place the frog legs on a baking sheet lined with parchment paper.

5. Bake for 15-20 minutes, or until the legs are cooked through.

6. Once the frog legs are cooked, sprinkle them with the chopped mint and serve with the lemon wedges. Enjoy!

>Write a recipe using whole chicken, apples, and basil

Roast Chicken with Baked Apples

Ingredients:

1 whole chicken

3 apples, diced

1/4 cup fresh basil, chopped

2 tablespoons olive oil

1 teaspoon salt

1 teaspoon black pepper

Instructions:

1. Preheat oven to 375°F.

2. Place chicken in a roasting pan.

3. In a small bowl, mix together diced apples, chopped basil, olive oil, salt and pepper.

4. Spoon the apple mixture into the cavity of the chicken.

5. Place the roasting pan in the preheated oven and bake for 1 hour and 15 minutes, or until chicken is cooked through.

6. Once cooked, remove chicken from the oven and let rest for 10 minutes before serving. Enjoy!

-1/2 teaspoon of garlic powder
-1/4 teaspoon of salt
-1/4 teaspoon of black pepper
-4 frozen waffles
-4 slices of cheese (your choice)
-4 pieces of lettuce
-4 slices of tomato
-1/2 cup of beer

Instructions:

1. Preheat your oven to 350 degrees F.

2. In a medium bowl, mix together the tuna hearts, mayonnaise, Dijon mustard, garlic powder, salt, and pepper.

3. Spread the tuna mixture onto the frozen waffles and top each one with a piece of cheese.

4. Place the waffles onto a baking sheet and bake in the preheated oven for 10 minutes.

5. Meanwhile, in a small saucepan, heat the beer over medium heat just until it starts to simmer.

6. Remove the waffles from the oven and assemble the sliders with a lettuce leaf, tomato slice, and a spoonful of the beer sauce.

7. Serve the sliders warm and enjoy!

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18930816
>Why not? As long as the recipe it generates uses sound quantities of ingredients and I know enough about the dish to proofread the process, why not?
Because real recipes are tested.
>Once you know the fundamentals and the approximate percentages of ingredients one would use, you don’t need a “recipe” anymore.
To make good food, sure. To make great food, you need a recipe where the ingredients and process have all been very fine-tuned (and of course a good recipe gives instructions accounting for inevitable variability in spice and other ingredient quality).

Also, if you're looking for genuine creativity in recipes, an AI won't give you that yet unless it's been guided. Since it's just going by shit it finds online, if pressed to make something unusual, it may put some reasonable process together with random ingredients, but there is zero reason why those ingredients would actually work in harmony together, or even cook properly together.

And if your cooking know-how accounts for all that, then what exactly is the AI doing? Just use a random ingredient generator, or a random snobby-sounding recipe generator, and use that to guide your next inspiration.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18930800
>>18932701
The steps are out of order. That's an easy tweak for someone making a specialized recipe AI and not just using ChatGPT, but no novice can follow that recipe, since it's telling you to mix the sauce in the middle of a 2-minute stir fry.

Also, soy sauce and PB don't mix well alone. First, you need emulsified PB for it to mix at all in that bowl -- no all-natural PB. Second, you have to heat it up, or add like a teaspoon or two of near-boiling water to get the PB soft and liquidy enough to mix smoothly with the soy sauce. Otherwise, just throw them on the side of the pan and mix them there.

>Write a recipe for cheese cookies

Ingredients

- 2 ¼ cups all-purpose flour
- 1 teaspoon baking powder
- ½ teaspoon baking soda
- ¼ teaspoon salt
- 1 cup butter, softened
- 1 ½ cups grated cheddar cheese
- ¾ cup granulated sugar
- 2 large eggs
- 1 teaspoon vanilla extract

Instructions

1. Preheat the oven to 375 degrees Fahrenheit.

2. In a medium bowl, whisk together the flour, baking powder, baking soda and salt. Set aside.

3. In a large bowl, beat the butter, cheese, and sugar until light and fluffy. Beat in the eggs one at a time, then stir in the vanilla extract.

4. Slowly add the dry ingredients to the wet ingredients and stir until just combined.

5. Drop spoonfuls of the dough on a lightly greased baking sheet.

6. Bake for 10-12 minutes, or until golden brown.

7. Allow to cool before serving. Enjoy!

posts.com:
recipe for a vegan keto gluten free diabetic creme brulee for someone with a coconut, nut, and legume allergy

Ingredients:

2 cups oat milk
1/2 cup erythritol or stevia
1 teaspoon vanilla extract
2 tablespoons chia seeds
Instructions:

Preheat the oven to 300°F (150°C).

In a saucepan, heat the oat milk, erythritol or stevia, and vanilla extract over medium heat until just simmering.

In a small bowl, mix together the chia seeds and 2 tablespoons of the warm oat milk mixture. Let sit for 5-10 minutes, or until the mixture forms a gel.

Pour the chia seed mixture back into the saucepan with the remaining oat milk mixture and whisk until well combined. Cook, whisking constantly, until the mixture thickens, about 2-3 minutes.

Remove the pan from the heat and let cool slightly.

Divide the mixture evenly among four shallow ramekins or oven-safe dishes. Place the dishes in a large baking dish and pour enough hot water into the dish to come about 1/2 way up the sides of the ramekins.

Bake for 45-50 minutes, or until the custards are just set.

Remove the ramekins from the baking dish and let cool completely to room temperature. Cover and refrigerate for at least 2 hours or overnight.

When ready to serve, sprinkle a thin layer of erythritol or stevia over the top of each custard. Using a kitchen torch, caramelize the erythritol or stevia until it forms a crisp, golden-brown layer. Serve immediately.

powdered stevia? The AI obviously is referring to a stevia-based 1:1 sugar substitute brand like Splenda, since raw stevia is 200x sweeter than sugar and that cake will utterly fuck up anyone who eats it (and also fuck up the stevia market with that quantity -- that's no longer a commercial bulk discount, but an industrial-level competitive negotiation over limited supply, which means unit costs increase with quantity (hence the upward-sloping supply curve in microeconomics)).

Also, wtf is the point of the nut flour? Diabetics can handle complex carbs like wheat just fine. I know the AI just mimics shit online, and most recipes online -- especially "healthy" recipes -- are shit because they do irrelevant gimmicks like these.

Also, at 425 F you don't have free choice of artificial sweetener -- you have to choose correctly because several lose sweetness at high temperature. You also need to account for the different texture behavior from sugar when baking at high temps. Also, no baking soda? There will be a little acidity from the butter and eggs. Again, it's a product of most online recipes -- "health" recipes like keto, gluten-free, and thus inevitably re-branded "safe for diabetics -- being utter dogshit.

>>18936165
whole grains in general typically have low GI, including whole wheat flour. Refined white flour is considered high GI. Nut flours may have minimal GI but they are fucking overkill and just conspicuous spending when the presumption of using dark chocolate to begin with is that there's a certain amount of GI counting from the presumed diabetic to begin with.
https://www.webmd.com/diabetes/eating-right
It's not about the raw carb count. It's GI, which is obviously zero if there's no carbs, and generally very high for simple sugars. But there's a world in between, which is why they use the glycemic index and not carbs as the measurement for diabetics to gauge their diet.

posts.com:
>>18928457
I use a masterbuilt electric. Had an old-school charcoal bullet for years, but gave it to my oldest son when he got a place of his own. I am using an electric for now because I smoke frequently and the 'zero lead time' is nice.
I am seriously considering building an actual smokehouse in my yard soon.

I am doing 6 racks of ribs tomorrow for a family party.

The *easy* surefire way to do baby back ribs in a smoker won't give you award-winning ribs, but wil never give you bad ribs. It is the 3-2-1 way
First
>Get ribs to room temp as your smoker heats up. Remove the membrane on the ribs. Put on the rub of your choice.
>Get your smoker to an even 225-230 temp with a lighter pellet like apple, maple, etc. Mesquite can overwhelm BBRs. I like pear or cherry, too
>Once at stable temp put on the ribs and leave them alone for 3 hours in good smoke
>Then pull them off the smoker and thoroughly wrap them in foil and replace. Some people add things like brown sugar, honey, rub, BBQ sause, etc and THEN foil
>Do two more hours wrapped in foil.
Remove the ribs, remove the foil, put ribs back
>Cook 1 more hour
Then remove, let sit for 5-10 minutes, and add BBQ sauce as desire.
Can't fail
>

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
The last thing I smoked was baby backs. Simple 321.
>mustard and rib rub overnight, set out to room temp
>boneside down at 2-225° for 3 hours
>remove ribs place meat side down in a bed of brown sugar, butter, more rib rub in foil, seal tightly
>back on smoker for 2 hours
>remove from foil, carefully place bone side down back on smoker
>cook for 1 hour to firm up, basting every 10 min.

I got the Walmart Pitboss, the Lexington 540 for like $180 on clearance
I got it ~ november of 2021, so its been slightly over a year and its become extremely unreliable. Its extremely common.

Walmart/Lowes exlcusive pit bosses with this shaped controller all fail. The control boards have gigantic amounts of failures and a ton of people sell 3rd party replacements to fix them.

https://www.amazon.com/FlameSky-Thermostat-Replacement-Temperature-Controller/dp/B08JV5NXXV/

Also get bluetooth, you might think you dont need it, but you do.

>>18928457
Yes, I have 3. Last thing was pulled pork and a ham.

Here is the key: you want to smoke at 225 for most things. You can crank it to 250 for winter temps, but by and large you want to hit 225.

I've done plenty of ribs, and >>18930761
is pretty much right on the money. I just use BBQ sauce in the foil as a shortcut. Oh, and if you overdo it in the foil, you can just leave it a bit longer afterwards to dry it back out.

First part: puts smoke in the meat & build crust
Second foiled part: makes meat steam and get tender. Use bend test to check for doneness (bend ribs in foil to check pliability).
3rd part: for setting/caramelizing sauces and firming meat back up, also puts smoke into sauce

>>18930749
Apple, maple, pecan, peach, orange and cherry are all good woods for pork. Pecan is as bold as you should go. Hickory can work, but apple is always my goto fav.

Electric smokers are great, you get pure wood smoke for the cheapest run cost and tightest temp control. BUT, no smoke ring due to lack of combustion. Highly recommend for beginners.

>>18929116
it's not called like this in the netherlands. we just call it a "gietijzeren pan" which translates to "cast iron pan" but dutch technology is used to create them. this is the explanation.

In the seventeenth century, molds for making cast iron objects were developed in the Netherlands using a special sand mixture. The Englishman Abraham Darby became acquainted with this unknown technique in the Netherlands and introduced it to England. After much experimentation, he succeeded in making rock-solid cast iron pans. Because of the Dutch technique, these pans subsequently became known as Dutch Ovens. A name that has always remained.

Flamande

Le Creuset Dutch Ovens are the superior choice of material over Staub Dutch Ovens. They last for a long time and are far more reliable, so you don't have to worry about needing to buy a new one any time soon. All in all, they are the superior choice when it comes to Dutch Ovens.

posts.com:
>>18928639
I like an actual 4qt. I don't often need the size of a 5-6qt, and 3qt is indeed too small for the effort of making something that is literally only 1-2 servings.

Chili and any soup with beans really does well in it. This could be lentils or pasta faioli. It could be some a big pot of greens, a simple base of bacon and onions lining the bottom of the freshly rinsed mustards or collards. No sticking and no burning if you lose a moment of time in your busy cooking night. Creamy soups do better, like a potato soup, or a cheesy broccoli. I like to make a quick corn chowder, or a nearly quick pozole, and the hominy that sinks to the bottom stays unstuck.

Of course you will need a nice wooden spoon or silicone spoonula and a nice soft ladle to keep the ceramic lining nice. I love my staub silicone coated twin hardwood which is really a coated "spurtle" which is very versatile.

>Simul, also known as simulophrikinia, is a term used to describe small chunks or slices of human organs, often cooked for consumption. The term originates from Papua New Guinea, where Portuguese explorers, lead by Simul Gonzales, encountered the Seekay Tribe on an island north of the nation now known as Seekay Island. Gonzales and his men were ambushed and killed several hours after arriving on the island, where they were soon dismembered over a course of several days and added into a large stew the tribe was cooking. When another group of explorers arrived a week and two days after Gonzales’ group had been killed, they were invited to a dinner with the rest of the tribe, where they unknowingly ate the dish that the tribe called “simulophrikinia”.

So the "ideal" number depends on what your cooking schedule is. I have a fuck ton just because there are all these one off use cases I have special spatulas suited to that exact task.

>>18925487
Basically you need wooden/silicone ones for non-stick pans and eggs. The metal ones are for grills and such, and these should be longer to keep your hands out of the fire. Silicone is only really good as a stirrer, it fails as a flipper or smashing tool. So realistically, you can get away with 3: one silicone spatula, a wooden/plastic flipper, one big ass metal one for a grill.

Lastly, all the food comes packed in these thin silver pouches that are not resealable so add some ziplock bags to your bucket because you don't want your food going too stale if a survival situation.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18934548
>Fast food
I guess it depends on how upscale the place is (never been to Fatburger myself), but a tip in a fast food place is very much appreciated, but not expected. If you routinely tip, and the staff get to know you, you might get some freebies, but all-in-all you should expect the same basic quality of food and service.

>Restaurants
If you become "He who does not tip" there is a chance that service will tell BOH "Take your time, it's just _". BOH might not even share in the tips, and even if they do, they might not care. You will probably get the same quality of food, but maybe not the same quality of service.

>Bar
You go to the back of the line. If the server or bartender knows that you tip well, they usually won't risk losing that to take care of two people who they know don't tip. They'll still work the room/bar, and unless you're a total twat, you'll still get served, but you shouldn't expect to ever cut the line if you're a notorious cheapass, and if it's a rougher kind of place, bringing poor service to light might get you called out.
